text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 4.25.14, Estate and Gift Tax, Miscellaneous Procedures.

IRM 4.25.14.6 paragraph (1) (a) was revised to clarify that Revenue Agents submit a referral through SRS to determine whether a consult is required prior to making a referral to the Estate and Gift WSD Coordinator. The contact information link was moved from paragraph (1)(a) to paragraph (1)(b).
This section contains instructions and guidelines for Small Business/Self Employed Estate and Gift Tax Programs employees.
Table of Contents

) General Overview - This IRM provides information about miscellaneous and gift tax examiner responsibilities, estate and gift tax IRM sections, and and forms used in the examination of estate, gift and generation skipping tax returns and claims. (

) Purpose - This IRM explains Estate and Gift examiner responsibilities so managers, senior-level officials and estate, gift and generation skipping tax return examiners will be better equipped to prepare and submit reports. (
) Audience - This IRM is for Estate and Gift Specialty Tax managers, and personnel at the Campus who process estate, gift and generation transfer tax returns, refunds and claims. (

) Policy Owner - Director, Examination - Specialty Policy is responsible for administration, procedures and updates related to the technical guidance information processing steps and methods speciﬁc to Estate and Gift Tax examiner responsibilities, IRM subsections, and forms created for the tion of returns and claims. (
) Program Owner - Director, Examination - Specialty Examination owns and Gift Tax Examination. (

) Primary Stakeholders - Advisory Collections, Appeals, Counsel, Estate Gift Tax Workload Selection and Delivery, Specialty Examination, and Examination Quality & Technical Support are the primary stakeholders for IRM. (

) This IRM subsection provides miscellaneous procedures associated with examination of estate, generation skipping transfer tax and gift tax returns. This IRM contains guidance related to extensions, liens and IDRS codes unique to estate and gift tax examinations, and links to various Servicewide resources. (

) Estate and gift tax examiners and managers assigned to examine and the examination of estate and gift tax returns and issues are responsible for complying with servicewide policies and authorities set forth in IRM
, Servicewide Policies and Authorities, Policy Statements for the Examining Process. (
) Examination of estate and gift tax returns should be conducted in a manner that will promote public conﬁdence as stated in the Mission of the Service. IRM
, and Policy Statement
) Policy Statement
established a general guideline that examination and processing of returns should be completed within
months of the ﬁling See IRM
, Policy Statement

) Estate and gift examiners and managers assigned to examine and oversee examination of international estate and gift tax returns and issues are sible for complying with all applicable servicewide examination delegation orders and SB/SE delegation orders. A table summarizing estate and gift egation orders is available at IRM
, Estate and Gift Tax, Miscellaneous Procedures, Signature Authority. (

) The National Quality Review System (NQRS) is a web-based review used by Estate and Gift Tax Policy, Estate and Gift Tax Examination and ment and Estate and Gift Tax Quality Measures and Analysis (QMA) to generate and review reports analyzing national quality performance based upon standardized quality attributes set forth in Document

, Estate Gift Tax Examination Embedded Quality Job Aid. NQRS report data is compiled by QMA on a quarterly basis, but ad hoc reports may be monthly. The use of NQRS is explained in additional detail in IRM
, Manager Embedded Quality Review and Specialty Exam National Quality Review Programs. (

) Operational Reviews and related NQRS reports are conducted by Territory Managers and the Chief of Estate and Gift to measure national adherence quality standards and managerial performance and/or oversight. (

) Customer (i.e. taxpayer) satisfaction reports are generated by SB/SE Operation Support Research on a quarterly basis. These reports provide masked taxpayer narratives that are responsive to a pre-deﬁned set of questions. The quarterly survey reports are to be used to identify areas for amination quality improvement. (
) Frequent Front-line manager reviews are conducted under the Examination Quality Review System (EQRS), with the frequency based on annual personnel requirements. (

) The following table sets forth Estate and Gift Tax program speciﬁc terms deﬁnitions: Term Deﬁnition Estate and Gift Tax Notebook Job This is a proprietary system Aid (Estate and Gift Notebook) comprised of an MS Office Access database and Excel ﬁles used by Estate and Gift Tax to generate reports and examination process and documentation (EPD). It is similar to RGS.

4.25.14.1.4 (07-13-2018) Terms/Deﬁnitions/Acronyms

Term Deﬁnition Estate and Gift Tax Notebook Job This is a proprietary system Aid (Estate and Gift Notebook) comprised of an MS Office Access database and Excel ﬁles used by Estate and Gift Tax to generate reports and examination process and documentation (EPD). It is similar to RGS.

page 3 Term Deﬁnition Substitute for Return IRC 6020(b) authorizes the creation of a substitute for Return (SFR). The SFR procedures allow the Service to establish an account when the taxpayer refuses or is unable to ﬁle a tax return and information received indicates that a return should be ﬁled. For example, a tax return prepared by an examiner when a taxpayer fails to ﬁle a return.

page 3 Term Deﬁnition Substitute for Return IRC 6020(b) authorizes the creation of a substitute for Return (SFR). The SFR procedures allow the Service to establish an account when the taxpayer refuses or is unable to ﬁle a tax return and information received indicates that a return should be ﬁled. For example, a tax return prepared by an examiner when a taxpayer fails to ﬁle a return. ) This section provides an introduction to extensions of time to ﬁle and to pay which are available to the taxpayer in estate and gift tax matters. (

) A request for an extension of time to ﬁle must be made by the due date of return. A request for an extension that is not timely may be granted upon a showing of good and sufficient cause. The processing of late-ﬁled extension requests and the factors for determining good and sufficient cause are discussed in IRM
, Campus Procedures For Estate Tax. (
) IRC
provides for the extension of time to ﬁle estate and gift tax returns. Form
, United States Estate (and Generation-Skipping Transfer) Tax Return, is generally due within nine months after the date of death. An estate may ﬁle Form
, Application for Extension of Time to File a Return Pay U.S. Estate (and Generation-Skipping Transfer) Taxes, to apply for an extension of time to ﬁle. (
) An estate may apply for an automatic six month extension of time to ﬁle a Form
, Form
-A, Form
-D, Form
-NA or Form
-QDT. the executor is out of the country, the maximum extension of time to ﬁle is months from the due date of the applicable return. (
) A request for an extension of time to ﬁle must be made by the due date of return. (
) No acknowledgement of the extension approval is sent to the taxpayer. (
) An extension of time to ﬁle does not extend the time to pay. (
) If the extension is APPROVED, Transaction Code (TC)
will be present transcripts followed by the approved extension date. (
) If the extension is DENIED, Transaction Code (TC)
will be present on scripts followed by “Denied”. (
) A Form
, United States Gift (and Generation-Skipping Transfer) Tax is generally due on April
following the close of the calendar year in which the gift was made. If the donor dies in the calendar year in which the donor - made a gift, the Form
is due on or before the due date of the estate tax return (including extensions), or on April
of the year following the calendar year of the gift, whichever date is earlier. (
) Except as provided in IRC
with respect to certain U.S. citizens and residents living outside the United States, an extension of time to ﬁle a gift return may not exceed six months from the due date of the return. See Reg.
) A request for an extension of time to ﬁle must be made by the original due date of the return, without extensions. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) An extension request may be made on Form

, the application for extension of time to pay shall in writing, shall state the period of extension requested and shall include a declaration that it is made under a penalty of perjury. (
) Any extension for time to pay will not be considered unless the extension is applied for on or before the date ﬁxed for payment of tax. (

) This section provides guidance with respect to the various types of estate gift tax liens as to which discharge may be applied for by taxpayers, their Requests resentatives, or other interested parties. Under IRC
, liens arise by of operation of law as to unpaid estate or gift tax. Effective ﬁscal year
, to the sponsibility for consideration of the release of property from these liens will fall to the Advisory Estate Tax Lien Group. See IRM
, Responsibilities for Processing Estate Tax Liens. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

This section provides guidance with respect to the various types of estate and gift tax liens as to which discharge may be applied for by taxpayers, their rep- resentatives, or other interested parties. Under IRC
, liens arise by operation of law as to unpaid estate or gift tax. Effective ﬁscal year
, re- sponsibility for consideration of the release of property from these unrecorded liens will fall to the Advisory Estate Tax Lien Group. See IRM
, Advisory Responsibilities for Processing Estate Tax Liens.
Procedures
) Discharge of property may be requested from the special recorded liens are unique to the estate tax area: • The lien under IRC
A that is provided to secure the interest of government as to assessed tax for which the payment is deferred to an election under IRC
• The lien under IRC
B that is provided to secure the interest of government as to potential recapture tax imposed under IRC and IRC

) Estate and Gift Examination will provide written communication of their mendations on issues such as ﬁling requirements; potential audit issues, Revenue Agent Report (RAR), or proper calculations of recapture tax within
business days. (
) IRC

(a) imposes, by operation of law, a lien for the estate tax upon gross estate of a decedent for a period of ten years from the date of death Under IRC (excepting such part of the gross estate as is used for the payment of against the estate and expenses of administration, allowed by any court jurisdiction thereof). This lien is a “silent” lien and is distinguished from other types of tax liens in that no recordation is required. (
) IRC

(b) imposes, by operation of law, a lien upon all gifts made during period for which a gift tax return is ﬁled and existing for a term of ten years from the date the gifts are made. Further, if the gift tax is not paid when the donee of any gift is personally liable for the gift tax due to the extent of value of the gift. This lien, like the IRC
(a) lien, is also an unrecorded (
) Certain exceptions exist, and application may be made to IRS by the for the discharge of speciﬁc items of property from the liens imposed under IRC
This is most commonly encountered with respect to the lien imposed with respect to estate tax under IRC
(a). If application is made on behalf of an estate, it must be ﬁled by the personal the estate, or a party properly authorized for representation pursuant to a power of attorney. (

, Application for Certiﬁcate Discharging Property Subject to Tax Lien, is usually submitted to request a discharge under IRC
, United States Certiﬁcate Discharging Property Subject to Estate Tax is used to approve the discharge of speciﬁcally described property under

Before any lien discharge is destroyed, current IDRS transcripts should be obtained to ensure that there is no balance owed on the account. Where such material remains in possession of a ﬁeld Estate and Gift group, a best practice is to destroy only after the assessment SOL has expired and with assurance that there is no outstanding balance on the tax module.

) Upon the determination of any tax liability, the Campus will prepare a Form in Estate Tax

, Transfer Certiﬁcate, in duplicate, for the Director, Campus Compliance Operations’ signature. The original will be issued once the tax liability has fully discharged, and the duplicate will be retained in the ﬁle. (
) An executor or other ﬁduciary may ﬁle a Form
, Request for Discharge from Personal Liability Under Internal Revenue Code Section
or

, for Discharge with respect to an estate or gift tax return. If the Service makes no Liability of determination of estate tax within nine months of the received dated of Revenue prompt assessment request, the executor is automatically discharged from
or personal liability (applying only to him in his personal capacity and his assets). However, if a ﬁduciary other than an executor ﬁles a Form
, IRS has six months to notify the ﬁduciary. See IRC
and IRC

a. The executor remains liable for assets of the estate that are in his pos- session or control. Also, the discharge does not release the estate from the lien for estate tax, if a deﬁciency is determined to be due. b. If the executor has applied for an extension of time in paying tax under IRC
, IRC
, or IRC

, a discharge from personal liability may still be requested. c. The Service has nine months to notify the executor of the amount of bond required to be posted. If no notice is given, the executor is dis- charged from personal liability. (

and IRC

) When revenue agents encounter a potential estate or gift tax issue during course of an examination, the following referral procedures should be Referrals a. Submit an SRS consultation request to determine if a referral is and Gift Tax warranted. b. If a referral is warranted, the revenue agent should complete the form located on the Estate and Gift website and e-mail it to the Estate and Gift WSD Referral Coordinator per the instructions on the referral form. The Coordinator’s contact information is located on the Estate Gift website. c. All relevant information/documentation, (i.e., secured Form
/Form original and/or amended, omitted assets, etc.) should be e-mailed (if sible) to the Estate and Gift WSD Referral Coordinator (address on the referral form). (

An executor or other ﬁduciary may ﬁle a Form
, Request for Discharge from Personal Liability Under Internal Revenue Code Section
or

, with respect to an estate or gift tax return. If the Service makes no notiﬁcation of determination of estate tax within nine months of the received dated of the prompt assessment request, the executor is automatically discharged from personal liability (applying only to him in his personal capacity and his personal assets). However, if a ﬁduciary other than an executor ﬁles a Form
, the IRS has six months to notify the ﬁduciary. See IRC
and IRC

a. The executor remains liable for assets of the estate that are in his pos- session or control. Also, the discharge does not release the estate from the lien for estate tax, if a deﬁciency is determined to be due. b. If the executor has applied for an extension of time in paying tax under IRC
, IRC
, or IRC

, a discharge from personal liability may still be requested. c. The Service has nine months to notify the executor of the amount of bond required to be posted. If no notice is given, the executor is dis- charged from personal liability.

warranted. If a referral is warranted, the revenue agent should complete the referral form located on the Estate and Gift website and e-mail it to the Estate and Gift WSD Referral Coordinator per the instructions on the referral form. The Coordinator’s contact information is located on the Estate and Gift website. All relevant information/documentation, (i.e., secured Form
/Form original and/or amended, omitted assets, etc.) should be e-mailed (if pos- sible) to the Estate and Gift WSD Referral Coordinator (address on the referral form).

) This section provides examination reopening procedures for estate tax where a Letter
, Estate Tax Closing Letter, was issued. Procedures (

) The estate and gift tax reopening case procedures vary depending on the Tax Returns manner in which the case was originally closed. Before an examiner that a case be reopened, the examiner should determine whether the case was accepted as ﬁled, surveyed, or examined. (
) A return in which Letter

, Estate Tax Closing Letter was issued as a of being “Accepted as Filed” or “Surveyed” can be opened for examination “Surveyed” the group manager’s approval. When making an examination determination as Filed” regarding this type of return, the reopening criteria should be considered. taxpayer should be advised of the reasons for the examination. (
) Reopening criteria include substantial error, fraud, malfeasance, and administrative error. Examples of reopening criteria, also called case return criteria, can be found at IRM
, Case Return Criteria. (
) The following procedures should be followed when attempting to reopen an examined case: an Examined a. Requests must include a completed Form

, Reopening dum, including narrative. b. Requests must be submitted via secure e-mail to the group manager review. All attachments and additional information will be included in same secure e-mail. Upon concurrence with the examiner’s tion the group manager will forward the e-mail to the Territory for signature approval. c. The Territory Manager will forward the completed electronic form to Estate and Gift, for signature. d. The completed signed form will be returned to the Territory Manager. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
J
Forward Form 3949 and the information detailed in IRM 4.1.1.6.11, Information
This section provides examination reopening procedures for estate tax where a Letter 627, Estate Tax Closing Letter, was issued.
Requests must include a completed Form

, Reopening Memoran- dum, including narrative. Requests must be submitted via secure e-mail to the group manager for review. All attachments and additional information will be included in the same secure e-mail. Upon concurrence with the examiner’s determina- tion the group manager will forward the e-mail to the Territory Manager for signature approval. The Territory Manager will forward the completed electronic form to Estate and Gift, for signature. The completed signed form will be returned to the Territory Manager.
) General guidance on the use of Suspicious Activity Reports (SAR) in Title
civil income tax cases is provided in IRM
, Bank Secrecy Act, Disclo- sure. (
) Employees in the estate and gift program authorized to electronically access SAR information are designated Gatekeepers. The designated Gatekeepers are paralegals within the WSD function. (

) Employees in the estate and gift program authorized to receive and use SAR information include: a. Estate Tax Attorneys b. Estate Tax Examiners c. Estate and Gift Group Managers d. Paralegals e. Legal Assistants f. Policy Attorney-Advisors and Analysts g. WSD Attorney-Advisors and Analysts (

) SAR information may be helpful in examination and case building activities when: a. Examiner has exhausted routine means of locating banking information b. Examiner has noted potential fraud indicators c. Taxpayer appears to be utilizing cash transactions to avoid reporting of income d. Taxpayer has made a voluntary disclosure and/or offshore bank are suspected e. Examiner is investigating a Whistleblower case involving unreported income, offshore bank accounts or activities, or f. The Web Currency and Banking Retrieval System (We
BRS) reﬂects a Currency Transaction Report (CTR). A CTR is ﬁled when a transaction occurs that involves currency exceeding $

) Training is required for access or use of SAR information. Completion of required training is a prerequisite to access or use of SAR information. In addition, managers of designated Gatekeepers or employees must ensure the employees they supervise have completed the required training before re- questing or receiving SAR information. Prior to completing any requests for SAR information, the designated Gatekeepers will ensure that the approving manager has completed the required training. The current requirements and course numbers can be located on ELMS. (
) To request SAR information:
Examiners will send an electronically completed Form
-A, Suspi- cious Activity Report (SAR) Document, request, by encrypted email to their group manager. Each request may contain multiple taxpayers.

The group manager indicates approval of the request after conﬁrming association with an active, assigned case, and forwards the approved request by encrypted e-mail to the Gatekeeper. This procedure satisﬁes the audit trail review requirement for employees using SAR data but not electronically accessing Web-CBRS. SAR audit trail reviews by of employees using SAR data only are not required where the manager checks each data request against the active inventory (of the employee, group, function, or project) prior to approving and forwarding the Form Internal Revenue Manual a # Only

If no SARs are found, the examiner will be notiﬁed via encrypted If SARs are found, the Gatekeeper will send the SAR information to requester using encrypted e-mail. Note: Examiners will contact a Fraud Technical Advisor if potential indicators are identiﬁed.
The Gatekeeper will maintain the approved electronic requests for a period of one year or until an audit trail review covering the time for those requests is completed, whichever occurs later. (

) Specialty requires audit trail reviews by supervisors of Gatekeepers to reconcile access with approved requests and further requires that managers ensure these reviews are conducted as required. Reviews will be conducted on an annual basis and may be conducted in conjunction with annual workload reviews. A
-day period will be selected from the prior
months of CBRS activity. The Gatekeeper will ensure queries were related assigned cases. (
) SAR information must be treated with the same security precautions as mation received from a conﬁdential informant, and is subject to both Title and Title
restrictions. See IRC

) The following also supplements IRM

and applies to maintenance disposal of SAR data in specialty cases, except case-building: a. SAR documents will be maintained in sealed conﬁdential envelopes within the case ﬁle. b. Attach Sensitive But Unclassiﬁed (SBU) Cover Sheet (TDF
) the outside of the envelope and to any ﬁle containing Form

-A SAR data. This cover sheet clearly identiﬁes documents that must be under the personal observation of an authorized IRS employee or maintained in a secured cabinet. c. The work papers, activity records, audit report or other documents the administrative ﬁle should not reveal or reference SARs. If necessary, use the term “conﬁdential informant”. d. No tax adjustments can be made solely based on SAR information. Examiners must independently develop the underlying issues (i.e., ported income) related to the SAR to support any potential e. Destroy all SAR-related material when closing a case. (

) Additional Information. For assistance in reviewing SAR information and guidance on how to use it, review the ELMS courses or contact a Gatekeeper. Questions may be submitted via e-mail to SBSE SAR Use. (

Note: Examiners will contact a Fraud Technical Advisor if potential fraud indicators are identiﬁed.
The following also supplements IRM 4.26.14 and applies to maintenance and disposal of SAR data in specialty cases, except case-building:
a. SAR documents will be maintained in sealed conﬁdential envelopes within the case ﬁle. b. Attach Sensitive But Unclassiﬁed (SBU) Cover Sheet (TDF
) to the outside of the envelope and to any ﬁle containing Form

-A or SAR data. This cover sheet clearly identiﬁes documents that must be under the personal observation of an authorized IRS employee or maintained in a secured cabinet. c. The work papers, activity records, audit report or other documents within the administrative ﬁle should not reveal or reference SARs. If absolutely necessary, use the term “conﬁdential informant”. d. No tax adjustments can be made solely based on SAR information. Examiners must independently develop the underlying issues (i.e., unre- ported income) related to the SAR to support any potential adjustments. e. Destroy all SAR-related material when closing a case.

) has been established to identify estate tax returns that have been examined and, as a result of the examination, the gross estate has increased to a value in excess of $

million. The activity code for the estates will not change since the activity code is intended to reﬂect the gross estate as reﬂected on the ﬁled return. j. Aging Reason Code

ERCS will be updated to reﬂect the aging reason code when applicable. The examiner should complete Form

(08-05-2016) MFT Codes used for Estate and Gift Tax Examinations
The common MFT codes used in estate and gift tax examinations are listed below. See Document 6209 for a full list of MFT codes.

A Project Code is a four digit number indicating that a case belongs to a special program which allows monitoring of the program by project code. AIMS reports can be generated for a given project to measure the total number of returns, examination time, results, etc.

tration (TIGTA) and the Office of Employee Protection (OEP) may apply a “Potentially Dangerous Taxpayer” (PDT) or a “Caution on Contact” (CAU) indicator. For more information regarding the determination criteria, and review of PDT and CAU indicators by TIGTA and OEP, see IRM
, Employee Protection, Potentially Dangerous Taxpayer and IRM

, Employee Protection, Caution Upon Contact Taxpayer. a. If a taxpayer is identiﬁed as a PDT, a PDT indicator will appear on the Examination Returns Control System (ERCS) screen and on the Inte- grated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) TXMOD transcripts. A complete of PDT code systems and documents can be found at IRM Exhibit

, Display of PDT Indicator. b. If a taxpayer is identiﬁed as CAU, a CAU indicator will appear on and on the TXMOD, IMFOL, BMFOL and INOLE transcripts. A list of CAU code systems and documents can be found at IRM Exhibit
, Display of CAU Indicator. (

) A taxpayer who meets PDT or CAU criteria should be approached with caution. A PDT designation takes precedence over a CAU designation. As a result, taxpayers who have been identiﬁed as PDTs cannot be designated with the CAU indicator. (

) Employees should promptly report assaults, threats, harassment or forcible interference incurred during, or related to, the performance of official duties their local Treasury Inspector General for Tax Administration (TIGTA) office. The Employee Resource Center contains a link to a list of TIGTA ﬁeld addresses and phone numbers. (
) Estate and Gift Tax examiners are responsible for following established ser- vicewide identity theft procedures. IRM
, BMF Identify Theft Procedures, provides servicewide guidance on BMF identity theft issues, including documentation and actions required for general processing of BMF Identify Theft (IDT) claims. (

) BMF identity indicators are not applied until required research has been completed to rule out possible mixed entity issue. Never assume identity prior to completion of the preliminary research. See IRM
for informa- tion regarding preliminary BMF research, and allegations or suspicions of case identity theft. (

) There is an ongoing Servicewide objective to eliminate and/or reduce SSN usage and reduce the overall reliance on the SSN as a primary identiﬁer. main initiatives have been masking the SSNs by implementing (

-D) barcode technology, and assessing the need for SSNs on forms and letters and removing or masking where possible. Estate and Gift Notebook generated documents and letters deploys letters and forms that contain masked SSN numbers where appropriate. (

) Most correspondence generated by estate and gift examiners to taxpayers does not require inclusion of a SSN. Estate and Gift Policy updated the letters and forms available through the Estate and Gift Notebook following guidance provided by PGLD. See Servicewide Memorandum OMB M-

a. If a taxpayer is identiﬁed as a PDT, a PDT indicator will appear on the Examination Returns Control System (ERCS) screen and on the Inte- grated Data Retrieval System (IDRS) TXMOD transcripts. A complete list of PDT code systems and documents can be found at IRM Exhibit

, Display of PDT Indicator. b. If a taxpayer is identiﬁed as CAU, a CAU indicator will appear on ERCS and on the TXMOD, IMFOL, BMFOL and INOLE transcripts. A complete list of CAU code systems and documents can be found at IRM Exhibit
, Display of CAU Indicator.

Most correspondence generated by estate and gift examiners to taxpayers does not require inclusion of a SSN. Estate and Gift Policy updated the pattern letters and forms available through the Estate and Gift Notebook following the guidance provided by PGLD. See Servicewide Memorandum OMB M-17-12,
Preparing for and Responding to a Breach of Personally Identiﬁable Informa- tion. See SSN guidance in IRM 10.5.1.7.14, Social Security Elimination and Reduction (SSN ER).
) House Resolution
, Social Security Number Fraud Prevention Act of was enacted into law on September
to further protect citizens from identity theft. H.R.
instructs federal agencies to restrict the inclusion of social security account numbers (SSNs) on federal documents sent by mail. The regulations specify that, “Not later than

years after the date of the enactment of this Act, the head of each CFO Act agency shall issue regula- tions specifying the circumstances under which inclusion of a SSN on a document sent by mail is necessary.” This gives the IRS until September
to meet these requirements.
